lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can write words and sentences (e.g., “Is he a doctor?”) clearly and accurately.
supportStrategies: (Writing) Model: “Is he a doctor?” on the board. Students copy, then write their own question and answer based on a picture from the SB.
stretchStrategies: Guess the Job Relay – Stronger students take on a leadership role in team games. They describe a job using clues (without saying the word) and classmates guess.
Example clues: He works at a school. He helps students. He isn’t a student.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can listen to spoken descriptions and select the correct job.
supportStrategies: (Listening) Say: “She works in a hospital.” “She helps sick people.” Students choose the correct job from multiple pictures.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can work together politely and take turns to play a competitive game.
supportStrategies: (4Cs – Competition) Divide class into teams. Ask job questions. First to answer correctly earns a point. Swap roles each round.

items: Consonant clusters do not exist in Vietnamese words, so they need special attention. Remember that clusters don't come only at the beginning of words – end clusters can be even harder (dogs, task, crisp, crisps, snacks)

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
